availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: Charles Nichols (Scott County, Kentucky, blacksmith, lumberer, and justice of the peace)

body.p: Scott County, Kentucky, blacksmith, lumberer, and justice of the peace. New York native. Married to Nancy B. Eckles Nichols in Scott County, Kentucky, on March 12, 1840. Father of Moses E. Nichols, Mary Ann Nichols, Charles E. Nichols, Samuel R. Nichols, Martha M. Nichols, and Daniel G. Nichols. Blacksmith in Scott County, Kentucky, in 1850. Owned six enslaved persons in Scott County in 1850. Blacksmith in Scott County in 1860. Lumberer in Scott County in 1860. Owned four enslaved persons in Scott County in 1860. Held four enslaved persons for various others in Scott County in 1860. Justice of the peace in Scott County until 1862.
